title: Riot, please, I beg you. Do me one favor. It'll be my birthday eventually. [Zoom-Out Functionality]
body:
Please seriously consider allowing players to zoom out further by default akin to Xerath and Jhin's ultimates.  I've considered the pros and cons, as seen below. 
---------------
**Pros**

- Helps out locked camera players to an incredible extent. I cannot stress how much it would help. I know people usually have no sympathy for locked-screen players, but there are many who just can't adjust to the camera system, and this would be a kind gesture which does no harm to the rest of the player-base. This is a significant limitation for me, and some others when it comes to the LoL experience. I've been playing locked-screen since Season 3. 

- Presumably not difficult to implement. We've already seen it applied to Xerath and Jhin's ultimates. I assume you'd just change a few camera-related global variables to bigger numbers. 
-------------------------
**Cons**

- Takes out a certain perceived difficulty or challenge. It's a skill to maneuver your camera properly and balance it with your mechanics. That said, it's a pretty artificial difficult. It doesn't arise from the game-play, it's a by-product of the interface. I believe it would just come down to some older players feeling slightly cheated 

- This quote from Riot jinxylord - "Zoom outs can only go so far before things start looking bad, FPS goes down, and possible buggy stuff gets more prevalent." The quote is taken from a thread where somebody wanted Xerath's ult-range increased. From the quote, it appeared that zooming out up to a range of 3500 (Jhin/Xerath's ultimate range)  is acceptable for current technology, but not more. I'd appreciate the zoom going as far as possible, but it doesn't even have to be 3500 units, just increase it to whatever you feel is fine in terms of textures/FPS/bugs. Just increase it, please. 
---------------
This topic is brought forth from time to time, but is never really considered because there isn't enough demand for it. According to statistics, there isn't much demand for the customizable item-sets either, but wouldn't it be nice to cater to certain niches of the community?  I'd be able to fight properly in the jungle, and actually see what's going on in team-fights. More so than mechanics, or map awareness, or strategy, this would result in the biggest improvement to my performance in games. ** Please seriously consider this matter. It would be the single most important improvement to LoL for me, and some others.** Thank you.

replies.body: Sounds like a personal issue.

It is a personal issue, but the topic has been brought up from time to time throughout the years. It only affects a small group of players, but I addressed that:

> According to statistics, there isn't much demand for the customizable item-sets either, but wouldn't it be nice to cater to certain niches of the community?

No, the item sets' popularity rose once they said they were going to delete it.  They also got a ton of feedback on _why_ people weren't using the feature, to which most replied "due to bugs and having to redo my sets every single patch" while others replied "we didn't even know it was there."  That's the reason why it's coming back.

Oh they are going to implement item sets in the new client? Good I was worried I would lose those. I hate searching through the shop during a game I like having a general build path with several "if this then these" options.

Yeah, it's pretty much 100%.  It'll be a few months before we get it back though.
I'm excited about it too^^

Well alright, I guess I'm wrong there. My point about the niche still stands though. Apparently the item-sets are something lots of people like, but weren't using because of x,y,z. This zoom-out feature has significantly less demand, but it does exist. You can search google for threads like this, and you'll see many over the years. I made one years ago as well, but gave up on it since people argued against it, just like they're doing now. 

This difference this time around is that Jhin/Xerath's ultimates have been implemented. When I first suggested the idea, even that wasn't there. Now there's a concrete idea of what it would look like. It's pretty depressing how people shoot down something as long as it's not relevant to *them*. Some people are giving meaningful critiques of why it's a bad idea, which is fine and should be weighed against the opposite arguments. Others are just against it for no real reason.

Yes, you are correct it's demanded frequently enough, but when they find out what they'd have to give up for it they usually cave.

If it was implemented (let's pretend), your suggestion would for sure need to have their built-in counterplay too.  If you're not against that then I no longer have an argument.  Your champ would basically at least need to constantly have a red range indicator on the ground.

Jhin and Xerath are rooted for the entire duration and there is a ground indicator telling the entire enemy team through FoW where they are if they want to jump them while ulting.

That's why Nami and Ashe are picked so frequently into them.  Both are basically yelling "free long-range skillshot hit through FoW here!"

Yes, it sounds dumb and excessive, but that would more than likely be the gameplay cost.

I don't understand any of the comparisons you just made with champions. Skill-indicators exist for many skills. Xerath and Jhin showing their maximum area is counter-play against those particular skills because they have ridiculous range, and people might want to leave the area. That doesn't apply to other champions just because a zoom-out feature is added. 

The built-in counterplay would be that it's harder to hit skillshots like Ahri's charm. I wouldn't stay zoomed out all the time anyway, only when I need to. Imagine zooming out like Jhin's ult and trying to play Yasuo. You might misclick minions for your dashes, you wouldn't be able to estimate whether or not your q will hit because the range at that zoom is too small. Nobody is going to stay zoomed out forever. It's basically a more powerful and different version of moving the camera.

> [{quoted}](name=Cynical Rain,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=eurohE8U,comment-id=000300000000000000000000,timestamp=2017-02-13T16:08:59.266+0000)
>
Nobody is going to stay zoomed out forever. 

That's the problem, you'll need to communicate when they do that to the enemy team since they're not giving up the view of their own champ in exchange for the view of somewhere else.  There needs to be a downside to zooming out.

>It's basically a more powerful and different version of moving the camera.

Yes, it is.  That's why there's such a debate about it being added.
So why can't you play unlocked? you said that there wasn't a choice for some people.

It's not a physical limitation, like playing on a laptop or something. It's a mental limitation. I just can't play with the camera like that, where firstly the camera isn't centered on my character. It's a very, very weird feeling exclusive to games like LoL/Dota if you've only played RPGs, Shooters, Racers, Platformers, etc. On top of that, you need to hit your window to move the camera. I've been playing LoL since S3, and I can't get used to it. I tried a few times, but it just doesn't work for me. If locked-screen didn't exist, I wouldn't play LoL.

You don't know how grateful I was to Riot when they implemented the slightly skewed locked-screens for purple-side. I can only hope that they accommodate even more.
Try holding down space until you use skillshots, it's basically locked camera with options.
riparoni
why not just use the map and ward?

Completely irrelevant. Consider a team-fight in the jungle where all of the bushes and relevant locations are warded. You can see the enemies on the mini-map, but you can't see them on your screen, so you're severely handicapped. The solution is to not play locked screen (not possible for some), or implement my suggestion.

Teleports can be seen within a certain radius through FoW.
Other champs (like Shaco) also leave particles in FoW that can be seen through the fog for counterplay if really paying attention.  Zooming out would make you auto-see them from the movement in the corner of your eye.

I have played mobas with the zoom out function and its useless too many people pay attention to other lanes instead of actually paying attention to their own lane the zoom out function is utterly useless
there's a better solution: stop playing locked camera

> I know people usually have no sympathy for locked-screen players, but there are many who just can't adjust to the camera system, and this would be a kind gesture which does no harm to the rest of the player-base.

Most of us are used to the current max zoom range, and occasionally zoom in, then just spin wheel back out to the total distance and leave it there. The game is also balanced around "screens away" in terms of vision. You might see someone on a ward on the minimap, but being able to see them on your own screen is a level of advantage you really shouldn't be given.

Point taken, I covered that in the cons section. 

> Takes out a certain perceived difficulty or challenge. It's a skill to maneuver your camera properly and balance it with your mechanics. That said, it's a pretty artificial difficulty. It doesn't arise from the game-play, it's a by-product of the interface. I believe it would just come down to some older players feeling cheated. 


As for being used to the current max-zoom, it would be a feature accessed through the settings. Nothing would change for players who don't want the change. Addressing the 2nd point, people who are used to non-locked screens could just hover over to the warded area, and see it, then switch back, or press that button which centers the camera on your character.

Again, there's zero difficulty to checking screens. You can even click on the mini-map to move it or just get used to putting your mouse at the edge of the screen. 

It's a game mechanic and it's easy enough for everyone else, so why can't you get over the handicap you give yourself by locking camera? If you had a physical disability that prevents you from moving the screen I could understand, but you're just being stubborn, so I have no sympathy for your ridiculous request.
It's not about checking screens. What about fighting in the jungle locked screen. The request is not ridiculous, nor am I am being stubborn.  Go fuck yourself with the condescension.

Why fight in the jungle on locked screen? You might as well play using one hand at that point.

Your request is ridiculous because it's pretty much universally accepted that locked screen is there for beginners and people who refuse to learn.

> [{quoted}](name=Cynical Rain,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=eurohE8U,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2017-02-13T15:10:36.179+0000)
>
> 

Just because you addressed it doesn't mean it's not a valid issue.  Stop playing locked camera.

Zooming out the camera wouldn't just be a _perceived loss of difficulty_ it would be an _actual loss of difficulty_.  Jungle ganking would be basically worthless if the jungler doesn't have an extreme gapcloser from FoW like Zac.  That's only one reason.  There are more.

Locked camera does have advantages, such as it being easier to cs and navigate fights without losing track of one's champion.  Unlocked camera gives those things up for a _different_ NOT _added_ view of the map.  You can be killed while looking somewhere else or miss someone sneaking up behind you if you're not paying attention (less likely to happen while locked if being careful).

tldr: both have pros and cons, don't just list the pros of one and all cons of the other.  People should learn to use both.

> Jungle ganking would be basically worthless if the jungler doesn't have an extreme gapcloser from FoW like Zac.

Not true at all. As seen in Jhin's and Xerath's ultimates, fog of war remains when you're zoomed out. I guess you could argue that you wouldn't have to look at the minimap, but it's practically impossible to miss a character on a ward on the minimap. People are used to looking at it constantly. 

I agree with the other point, it's a different view of the map, which is the result of interface, not gameplay. As for your tl;dr, I have no idea what you're talking about, I have negatives and positives.

You only listed the pros and cons of implementing the change,
not of the actual camera options themselves.

If I may politely ask, how long have you been playing for?
I'm asking that because, contrary to popular belief, people do not look at the minimap as often as you'd think.  For example, if you know it's warded for sure, you can still gank if you wait for the caddy-minion wave.  They'll be so entranced by it you'll probably be able to walk right next to them without them noticing.
Another example is let's say you're playing mid and ping "missing" but your laner still roams bot or top and kills them.  You may be thinking "wtf, I pinged" but your bot or top isn't looking mid for the missing pings.  You need to ping missing on mid and then danger at the very tips of both rivers for them to actually notice the roam.

I've been playing since S3, so about 4 years. I get what you're saying, and it would apply to newer or "nooby" players I guess. I'm not all that good myself, but a Jungler would never be able to cross through a ward without me seeing him unless it's literally in the split seconds when an enemy laner all-ins me. I'd be too focused on the fight, and wouldn't look at the minimap. When I play support, it's practically impossible for me to miss someone in a warded bush, even all the way across the map.

Nah, it's not about "noobyness" I was just legit wondering because I find full locked-screen harder (my brother taught me and pressed Y on me and I didn't know how to get it back^^").

We're from the sameish join-time.  Have you tried the third offset camera option yet?
Not per-side or normal, but the third one they added that allows you to set your own offset.
I heard it was a decent middle-ground but takes a bit of time to get used to.

I didn't know that existed. I tried a third part software which did that back in the day, and it was kind of helpful, but a native zoom-out implementation would be so much better. I'll check out this feature, I'm sure it'll help somewhat.

Edit: Just tried it, it's basically not locked screen except you won't accidentally move the camera so far away that you don't see your character. I'm glad Riot implemented it to help some players, but this wouldn't help me at all.

Yeah, it's pretty good (so I've been told) but don't give up on it right away.
I've also been told it's tricky to get used to at first.

The zoom feature you are requesting would never be implemented only for locked camera as it would make it unfair by allowing you to see more of the map on the same sized screen than people playing with unlocked.  Sure you can move the camera around but for every pixel you move it up you lose a pixel of vision on the bottom side.   

They also wouldn't implement it for both modes because a. what Riot Jinxlord said and b. the game is designed and balanced around the fact that players receive x amount of vision on their screens and it is even used as a form of measurement when talking about distance in the game such as "he landed that varus q from a screen away".  Sure the varus had his camera probably unlocked and on the enenmy but that means he can't see himself or where he is.

I reccomend practising with unlocked during laning phase by moving your mouse to the edge of the screen to see how much it moves and how fast and using the space bar to recenter yourself if you ever go to far.  Literally just keep practising moving the camera every laning phase or when you walk back to lane, lots of pros play with locked in laning and then only unlock it when they want to take a quick look around or in teamfights.

Your argument about balancing around limited-vision is justified, but would removing that layer of difficulty really be detrimental? Would you miss it? Would you think it makes LoL too easy? I can't see it as anything more than an artificial difficulty. You're not going to stay zoomed out forever, it would be harder to land skillshots or cs. It's basically a different (but admittedly more powerful) screen adjustment. I'd zoom out to observe then zoom back in. I'd stay zoomed out for fights in the jungle, but then it's harder to land skillshots like Ahri's charm - a trade-off I'd be happy with.

> Takes out a certain perceived difficulty or challenge. It's a skill to maneuver your camera properly and balance it with your mechanics. That said, it's a pretty artificial difficult. 

It's literally as "difficult" or "challenging" as using a mouse to click where you want to go. 

Do you left click? Do you right click? Do you move using the scroll wheel? Is the mouse movement inverted?! SO DIFFICULT!!! /s

Both of them are mechanics that have been around since the early days of PC gaming, and are still used because of how well they works. If you're struggling with that then it's a personal problem.

> It doesn't arise from the game-play, it's a by-product of the interface. I believe it would just come down to some older players feeling slightly cheated

Actually it does arise from gameplay considerations. 

Vision is restricted to allow for things to sneak up on you. If you can see the entire map all at once l then you'll be *very* aware when Top or Mid goes MIA or when Bot starts Dragon, far moreso than if you're just using the minimap. That changes the focus of the gameplay, making it more like an RTS than a MOBA. 

If you want a game focused more on strategy, you show more of the map. If you want a game focused more on mechanics, you show less of the map. League tries to strike the middle ground.

-------

As a side note, I *really* don't like the zoom out as {{champion:101}} . The camera angle doesn't line up the way you expect at the edges of the field of view, resulting in easier to miss skillshots. Yeah, you can see more map (it's a strategy focused ult) but that only helps with target selection, not with execution.
